## 1 Straight Line

![](images/Q01.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

Perpendicular bisectors pass through the *midpoint* of a line segment, and run *perpendicular* to them.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$4y=3x-6$ or $y=\frac{3}{4}x-\frac{3}{2}$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/A01.png)

`r unhide()`

![](images/Q02.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

A straight line equation must be rearranged to make $y$ the subject ($y=\dots$) before its gradient can be determined.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$2y=-x-5$ or $y=-\frac{1}{2}x-\frac{5}{2}$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/A02.png)

`r unhide()`

![](images/Q03.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

The formula $m=\tan{\theta}$ links a line's gradient to the angle it makes *with the positive direction of the *$x$*-axis*.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$y=-x-2$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/A03.png)

`r unhide()`

<hr>

![](images/Q04.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

Calculate the gradients of PQ and QR first. The conclusion to a collinearity problem needs to be learned *carefully*.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$m_{PQ}=m_{QR}=-3$, valid statement

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/A04.png)

`r unhide()`

![](images/Q05.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

Check the properties of *altitudes* and *medians* of triangles using your notes. Once you have obtained each equation, check that it *matches the diagram* in terms of gradient and $y$-intercept.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

(a) $y=-3x-5$ (b) $2y=-x-5$ or $y=-\frac{1}{2}x-\frac{5}{2}$ (c) $(3,-4)$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/A05.png)

`r unhide()`
